webTitle: EasyJet soars after upgrade, but Man falls back on negative comment

fields.standfirst: Budget airline among top FTSE 100 risers after JP Morgan turns positive and more than doubles price target
fields.body:
Better late than never for easyJet.

No, not anything to do with the budget airline's arrival times. Rather it's directed at analysts at JP Morgan, who have just decided their view of the airline might need updating.

In a note on the whole sector, the bank suggested that a restructuring of legacy airlines in Europe, along the lines of events in the US, was unlikely, meaning discounters like easyJet should continue to thrive.

So it has raised its rating on easyJet from underweight to overweight, and hiked its target price from just 625p to £15.40. This seems a little behind the curve, since easyJet has not been anywhere near 600p since November last year, and the airline has grown so valuable that it joined the FTSE 100 in March.

Nevertheless, JP Morgan's recommendation helped lift easyJet another 46p to £13.96.

Elsewhere hedge fund group Man also reacted to a broker note, this time a negative one. Its shares have fallen 2.45p to 86.7p after RBC Capital Markets moved from sector perform to underperform and reduced its price target from 120p to 85p. Analyst Peter Lenardos said:

Man is on track to report its eighth consecutive quarter of net outflows. Net outflows began in the third quarter of 2011 and we forecast a net outflow for the second quarter of 2013 of $2.1bn. Man continues to suffer asset withdrawals whereas most other asset managers are reporting net inflows.
Man should post declines on all key income statement metrics. We forecast that Man will report lower revenue (-12%), pretax profit (-31%) and earnings per share (-38%) in the first half of 2013, and will declare a dramatically lower interim dividend (-79%). [Key fund] AHL had a volatile quarter, increasing by 8% to near its high watermark, and then plunging 14% to end the quarter at its low. Our level of caution remains elevated as earnings visibility has declined, and we continue to believe the shares should be avoided for investment purposes until the business shows signs of stability.

webTitle: Sports Direct staff set to share £140m bonus pool as store enjoys record year

fields.standfirst: Retailer drops controversial 'super-stretch bonus share scheme' for founder and majority shareholder Mike Ashley
fields.body:
Sports Direct has reported a record year boosted by the London Olympics and Uefa European Championships, with staff in line to share a £140m bonus pool next month.

The clothing retailer is also dropping a controversial bonus share scheme for Mike Ashley – founder, majority shareholder and deputy chairman.

It said on Thursday it would instead explore "various options" to reward him after the "super-stretch bonus share scheme" failed to gain sufficient shareholder support last year and the company abandoned the proposals, which would have seen a potential £26m paid out to Ashley, owner of Newcastle United. The board withdrew the resolution at its annual meeting in September, but in December had said it remained "committed" to the scheme.

Sports Direct made a pre-tax profit of £207.2m in the 52 weeks to 28 April, described by the chief executive, Dave Forsey, as a "record-breaking year for the group and for British sport".

The FTSE 250 company's share price has risen more than 90% over the past year, helping staff to meet bonus targets.

Around 2,000 staff will next month receive an average of 12,000 shares, worth around £72,000 at the current share price, as part of a 2009 bonus scheme.

The company said two of four targets outlined in a further 2011 scheme had also been met.

Revenue in the full-year rose 20.9% to £2.2bn, but the retailer said it would not be proposing a dividend.

"The board feels that it remains in the best interests of the company and its shareholders to maintain financial and strategic flexibility, including pursuit of potential acquisition opportunities and ongoing investment in group infrastructure and store portfolio," it said.

"The payment of dividends will remain under review for consideration in future years."

webTitle: WPP rises after rival's results while Marks rises on bid talk

fields.standfirst: Leading shares move higher after Bernanke testimony with advertising group lifted by Publicis figures
fields.body:
WPP is helping the market move higher after better than expected results from one of the advertising group's rivals.

French group Publicis reported strong sales growth, lifting WPP 31p to £11.99.

Meanwhile Marks & Spencer has risen 9.8p to 483.4p on a revival of bid stories, with US predators mentioned this time around.

The London Stock Exchange has added 56p to £15.36 after first quarter revenues rose 39% to £249.7m, helped by the acquisition of clearing house LCH Clearnet and an increase in the number of companies seeking listings.

So overall, despite continuing concerns about Chinese growth after downbeat comments on the country's economy from the IMF, the FTSE 100 has climbed 30.11 to 6602.04. Investors were comforted by US Federal Reserve chairman Ben Bernanke's comments in front of Congress on Wednesday, where he played down the idea that the Fed would soon turn off the money taps. Ishaq Siddiqi, market strategist at ETX Capital, said:

Bernanke's statement reiterated last week's rhetoric that tapering quantitative easing has not been set in advance and remains dependent on the performance of the US economic recovery. Traders were expecting a dovish Bernanke and that's exactly what they got, so with little fresh said, stocks markets are holding steady ahead of the second day of his testimony [on Thursday] which may offer more insight, particularly as there is no scheduled press conference for the July FOMC meeting. The testimony so far appears to be an attempt by Bernanke to communicate his message more explicitly to markets which have been left perplexed ever since he let the tapering genie out of the bottle.

Among the fallers, Tate and Lyle has lost 20p to 839.5p as Societe Generale cut its recommendation from buy to hold ahead of the sweetener specialist's update next week. It said:

With significantly lower sugar prices, falling Mexican US high fructose core syrup imports, and a continued structural syrup decline in the US, the balance of power in the upcoming calendar 2014 pricing negotiations is likely to shift back to carbonated soft drink producers. After three favourable years for the corn processors, this is likely to weigh on [Tate's] bulk Ingredients profits going forward.
